sections.title: Market Pulse: Mixed Signals Amid Cooling Inflation

items.headline: U.S. Markets Close Week Lower Despite Friday's Modest Gains and Easing Inflation
items.summary: U.S. stock markets concluded the trading week on Friday, February 14, 2026, with major indices generally in the red for the week, although some pared losses by Friday's close. The sentiment was influenced by a cooler-than-expected January inflation report, which saw consumer prices growing at an annual rate of 2.4%, down from 2.7% in December. This data led to a drop in mortgage rates. However, broader market concerns, particularly around the high costs and potential disruptive impact of artificial intelligence on certain tech sectors, continued to weigh on investor confidence. While the S&P 500 and Dow were largely unchanged or slightly up on Friday, the Nasdaq Composite saw a modest gain. The Federal Reserve maintains a neutral rate stance, with market probabilities suggesting rates will remain unchanged in the near term.

items.headline: Nike Leads Dow Gainers
items.summary: Nike ($NKE) saw a significant increase on Friday.

items.headline: UnitedHealth Group Rises
items.summary: UnitedHealth Group ($UNH) posted strong gains during Friday's session.

items.headline: Walt Disney Company Up
items.summary: The Walt Disney Company ($DIS) closed higher on Friday.

items.headline: Visa Among Day's Losers
items.summary: Visa ($V) experienced a notable decline by Friday's close.

items.headline: Apple Shares Dip
items.summary: Apple ($AAPL) shares moved lower during Friday's trading.

items.headline: Nvidia Falls Amid Tech Volatility
items.summary: Nvidia ($NVDA) closed down, reflecting ongoing volatility in the technology sector.

items.headline: Technology Sector Faces Headwinds from AI Concerns
items.summary: The technology sector experienced heavy selling this week, with investors showing caution due to fears that artificial intelligence advancements could make some programming and non-hardware tech companies obsolete. Despite strong earnings growth in information technology, the sector's ETF has fallen over the past month, indicating that AI-related anxieties are outweighing positive results.

items.headline: Energy and Industrials See Inflow as Investors Seek Defensive Positions
items.summary: In contrast to the tech sector, defensive consumer-staples names, energy, and industrials have seen increased investor interest. The energy sector, in particular, was the best performer among S&P 500 sectors over the past month, surging 15.6%, as investors seek more stable opportunities amidst market uncertainties.

items.headline: January CPI Cools, Jobs Report Stronger Than Expected
items.summary: Key economic data released this week showed a mixed picture. The Consumer Price Index (CPI) for January indicated cooling inflation, with an annual rate of 2.4%, down from 2.7% in December. This data positively impacted mortgage rates. Concurrently, the U.S. Non-Farm Payrolls (NFP) report revealed 130,000 new jobs in January, exceeding forecasts, and the unemployment rate dropped to 4.3%.

items.headline: Major Earnings on Deck for Next Week
items.summary: With fourth-quarter earnings season largely wrapped up, attention turns to upcoming reports. Walmart ($WMT) is scheduled to report next week, with analysts keenly watching for insights into discretionary consumer spending and the impact of AI on the retail giant. Other companies like DoorDash ($DASH), Palo Alto Networks ($PANW), Etsy ($ETSY), Wayfair ($W), Wingstop ($WING), Deere & Co. ($DE), and Live Nation Entertainment ($LYV) are also set to release their results.
